articles.title: Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase share losses contribute to Dow's 316-point fall
articles.author: MarketWatch Automation
articles.excerpt: Dragged down by losses for shares of Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is declining Tuesday morning. The Dow was most...
articles.summary:
Dragged down by losses for shares of Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is declining Tuesday morning. The Dow 
DJIA, 
-0.95%
 was most recently trading 316 points, or 0.9%, lower, as shares of Goldman Sachs 
GS, 
-2.83%
 and JPMorgan Chase 
JPM, 
-2.00%
 are contributing to the index's intraday decline. Goldman Sachs's shares are off $10.82 (3.0%) while those of JPMorgan Chase have fallen $3.79 (2.4%), combining for a roughly 96-point drag on the Dow. Also contributing significantly to the decline are Intel 
INTC, 
-2.

articles.title: JPMorgan Chase Unusual Options Activity For August 09
articles.author: Benzinga Insights
articles.summary:
Someone with a lot of money to spend has taken a bullish stance on 
JPMorgan Chase
 
JPM
.
And retail traders should know.
We noticed this today when the big position showed up on publicly available options history that we track here at Benzinga.
Whether this is an institution or just a wealthy individual, we don't know. But when something this big happens with JPM, it often means somebody knows something is about to happen.
So how do we know what this whale just did? 
Today, 
Benzinga
's options scanner spotted 16 uncommon options trades for JPMorgan Chase.

articles.title: Advancing Black Wealth Tour Coming to Oakland & Chicago in August
articles.author: Business Wire
articles.excerpt: OAKLAND, August 07, 2023--JPMorgan Chase is excited to announce the return of its Advancing Black Wealth Tour. The multi-city event series, now in its second year, delivers financial health education,…
articles.summary:
Multi-city event returns for 2023 to empower Black community with financial insights on homeownership, entrepreneurship and investing
Oakland (8/12) headlined by Stephen Curry and Ian Dunlap
Chicago (8/26) to be headlined by Kevin Hart
Presented by JPMorgan Chase, the tour will also visit New York City and Miami later this year
OAKLAND, August 07, 2023--(BUSINESS WIRE)--JPMorgan Chase is excited to announce the return of its Advancing Black Wealth Tour. The multi-city event series, now in its second year, delivers financial health education, home-buying and real estate workshops, wealth building seminars and other vital financial insights to Black communities nationwide.

articles.title: JPMorgan Chase's ‘Advancing Black Wealth Tour' Heads To Oakland And Chicago On Multi-City Tour
articles.author: Derek Major
articles.excerpt: JPMorgan Chase's multi-city "Advancing Black Wealth Tour," which delivers financial education to Black communities, is returning.
articles.summary:
August 9, 2023
August 9, 2023
26
 
0
 
 
 
 
JPMorgan Chase's 'Advancing Black Wealth Tour,' a multi-city series delivering financial health education and real estate workshops to Black communities nationwide is back. 
 
The tour, which is in its second year, will stop in four cities. The first two stops are in Oakland, CA, on August 13, 2023, and Chicago on August 26, 2023. 


Each stop will bring together prominent business leaders, entrepreneurs, investors, and talent to help Black communities with wealth-building, home-buying, and other vital financial insights.

articles.title: JPMorgan ‘Trying to Lead' In Carbon Removal, Bank Says
articles.author: Michelle Ma
articles.excerpt: The bank is jumping into the carbon removal market, and Brian DiMarino, its head of operational sustainability, is the driving force.
articles.summary:
JPMorgan Chase & Co. made waves in May when it announced it would purchase $200 million of carbon dioxide removal. Though it's a relatively small investment for a bank JPMorgan's size, it's one of the largest corporate buys of carbon removal and could be a huge boon to the nascent industry to pull carbon out of the air.

Brian DiMarino, managing director and head of operational sustainability at JPMorgan, was the driving force behind the precedent-setting move in the financial services industry. The flow of money could help the industry scale up in the coming decades, which it will likely need to do if the world is to avoid catastrophic climate change.

articles.title: JPMorgan says it expects to pay about $3 billion to help refill FDIC fund

JPMorgan Chase Bank is seen in New York City, U.S., March 21, 2023. REUTERS/Caitlin Ochs

NEW YORK, Aug 3 (Reuters) - JPMorgan Chase (JPM.N) said it would need to set aside nearly $3 billion to replenish a government deposit insurance fund, once rules are finalized, according to a regulatory filing on Thursday.

articles.title: Prosecutors Accused of Pressuring Frank Founder Javice With Suit-Delay Request
articles.author: Jef Feeley
articles.excerpt: Charlie Javice accused US prosecutors of trying to turn up the heat in the criminal fraud case against her by blocking information exchanges in a separate lawsuit filed by JPMorgan Chase & Co., which…
articles.summary:
(Bloomberg) -- Charlie Javice accused US prosecutors of trying to turn up the heat in the criminal fraud case against her by blocking information exchanges in a separate lawsuit filed by JPMorgan Chase & Co., which claims she tricked the bank into buying her Frank college financial-planning website. 
There's no legitimate reason for prosecutors to halt discovery in the Delaware civil case so that Javice can't use it to bolster defenses in the criminal case, her attorneys said in a court filing. Javice and a colleague were charged with defrauding JPMorgan when it acquired Frank for $175 million and made them executives at the bank.

articles.title: JPMorgan Chase opens bank branches in Mass which other banks close them
Gee, I wonder why JP Morgan Chase has been closing Arab and Muslim bank accounts in Michigan?
articles.author: BareNakedIslam
articles.excerpt: Terror-linked CAIR claims it is discrimination based on religion or ethnicity. Well, they are partly right. Muslims are required to donate part of their income, ‘zakat,' to their mosque…
articles.summary:
One of the latest reported incidents, according to CAIR–MI, involved Alif Arabic, a business described as teaching Arabic to American citizens online. Officials there were notified May 30 by JPMorgan Chase their bank account would be terminated within 10 days. JPMorgan Chase officials did not detail why, according to the letter.


When an Alif Arabic employee asked the bank for clarification, they were told an analytical tool 'alerted them that Alif's account could pose a possible risk,' the letter read.
articles.authors: BareNakedIslam,Conrad Calvano,Daniel Erbstoesser,Ron Homan,Susan K,Us Infidel

 Banks in the United Kingdom are being accused of instituting their own 
private social credit score systems
 as they routinely "debank" individuals whose politics do not align with their own.
The first British bank to be accused of debanking is Coutts, a private bank owned by the finance conglomerate NatWest. articles.title: Banks Seek to Dispose of Unattractive Property Loans
articles.author: Madeline Beaumont
articles.excerpt: – Banks are struggling to sell commercial-property loans due to a lack of options for an easy exit.– Lenders like Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase have
articles.summary: – Banks are struggling to sell commercial-property loans due to a lack of options for an easy exit.– Lenders like Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase have been attempting to sell debt backed by various types of properties, but are facing challenges.– Concerns about commercial real estate have surged, making it difficult for banks to tidy up their loan books.– The market for commercial-property loans has dried up, making it harder for banks to find buyers.– Selling these loans has become a complex task for banks, as they navigate the current market conditions.

articles.title: JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon: Epstein Lawsuits Only Hurt Brand Name ‘a Little Bit'
articles.author: Kate Briquelet
articles.excerpt: The banking honcho doubled down on claims that JPMorgan didn't realize Epstein was running an international sex-trafficking operation.
articles.summary:
Carlo Allegri/Reuters
In an interview with CNBC, JPMorgan Chase 
CEO Jamie Dimon
 said the litigation surrounding the 
bank's relationship
 with Jeffrey Epstein has only impacted its brand equity 'a little bit sometimes.' His comments arrive amid 
a legal battle
 with the U.S. Virgin Islands, which has accused the bank of enabling Epstein's sex trafficking and 
cited internal emails
 showing the bank disregarded red flags about his activities. In June, JPMorgan agreed to settle another lawsuit filed by Epstein victims 
for $290 million
.

articles.title: Risky Credit Recovery Rates Hit Record Lows, JPMorgan Says
articles.author: Olivia Raimonde
articles.excerpt: The amount of money investors are poised to get back from corporations that defaulted on their debt fell to a record low, according to JPMorgan Chase & Co.
articles.summary:
The amount of money investors are poised to get back from corporations that defaulted on their debt fell to a record low, according to JPMorgan Chase & Co.

Recoveries for high-yield bonds and leveraged loans over the last 12 months are 19.6% and 39.7%, well below its 25-year and 24-year annual averages of 40.2% and 64.3%, respectively, the lender said in a credit research report Thursday.

articles.title: Big Bank Stocks Slide Following Regional Downgrades
articles.author: Jack Pitcher
articles.excerpt: Shares of Bank of America, JPMorgan Chase and Citigroup were all down 2% or more after Moody's cut the credit rating of 10 smaller U.S. banks and said it was reviewing the ratings of six larger ones. The ratings firm said the Federal Reserve's campaign to lift interest rates to combat inflation "continues to have a material impact on the US banking system's funding and its economic capital."

articles.title: JPMorgan scraps recession call in latest sign of rising optimism
articles.author: Crain's New York Business
articles.excerpt: The move follows a growing number of forecasters who now expect the economy to avert a downturn.
articles.summary:
JPMorgan Chase economists scrapped their call for a recession in the U.S., joining a growing number of forecasters who now expect the economy to avert the downturn that was once viewed as inevitable.

The bank, which had previously said it expected a recession to begin in 2023, now sees continued expansion this year and 'modest, sub-par growth' in 2024 as the most likely scenario. Michael Feroli, chief U.S. economist at the bank, flagged the rising possibility of 'healthy non-inflationary growth' thanks to potential productivity gains from artificial intelligence and a pickup in labor supply.

articles.title: Valerie Wilson Travel co-presidents promoted to positions at parent company
articles.author: Jamie Biesiada
articles.excerpt: Chase Travel has named Jennifer Wilson-Buttigieg its head of policy and Kimberly Wilson Wetty head of travel brand culture.
articles.summary:
Chase Travel has named Jennifer Wilson-Buttigieg its head of policy and Kimberly Wilson Wetty head of travel brand culture.

The sisters were previously co-presidents of Valerie Wilson Travel, which was acquired by Frosch International in 2021. Frosch, including all of its divisions and brands, was acquired by JPMorgan Chase & Co. last year.

Karen Magee

Karen Magee, formerly senior vice president of business transformation at Global Travel Collection, Internova's luxury division, has been named president of Valerie Wilson Travel beginning in September.

articles.title: Property Loans Are So Unappealing That Banks Want to Dump Them
articles.author: Natalie Wong
articles.excerpt: Banks seeking to sell commercial-property loans are encountering a dried-up market with few options for an easy exit.
articles.summary:
By

Banks seeking to sell commercial-property loans are encountering a dried-up market with few options for an easy exit.

Lenders including Goldman Sachs Group Inc. and JPMorgan Chase & Co. have been trying to sell debt backed by offices, hotels and even apartments in recent months, but many are finding that tidying up loan books is no easy feat when concerns about commercial real estate have surged.

articles.title: JPMorgan says it expects to pay about $3 billion to help refill FDIC fund
articles.author: Reuters
articles.excerpt: JPMorgan Chase expects to set aside about $3 billion to replenish the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's (FDIC) fund once proposed rules are finalized by the bank regulator, the company said in a filing on Thursday.
articles.summary:
JPMorgan Chase expects to set aside about $3 billion to replenish the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's (FDIC) fund once proposed rules are finalized by the bank regulator, the company said in a filing on Thursday.

US banking giants are expected to shoulder the bulk of costs to refill the fund, which was drained of $16 billion this year after three banks collapsed.

Wells Fargo estimated it will face a pretax 'special assessment' of up to $1.8 billion, while Bank of America said it could face a pretax expense of about $1.

articles.title: Jamie Dimon, JPMorgan board defeat shareholders' Jeffrey Epstein lawsuit
articles.author: Syndicated Content
articles.excerpt: By Jonathan Stempel NEW YORK (Reuters) - A federal judge has dismissed a shareholder lawsuit accusing JPMorgan Chase Chief Executive Jamie Dimon and h...
articles.summary:
By Jonathan Stempel
NEW YORK (Reuters) – A federal judge has dismissed a shareholder lawsuit accusing JPMorgan Chase Chief Executive Jamie Dimon and his board of directors of ignoring red flags surrounding disgraced former client Jeffrey Epstein.
In a Wednesday evening decision, U.S. District Judge Jed Rakoff said shareholders led by Miami and Pittsburgh pension funds failed to first ask the bank's board directly to address their concerns, or show it would be futile to do so, before suing.
The Manhattan-based judge said he will explain his reasoning in due course.

Sponsored by JPMorgan Chase & Co.

Inspiration was around every corner at the National Association of Black Journalist's Annual Convention held Aug. 2-6 in Birmingham. Every discussion held the unmistakable tone of opportunity. Every conversation more energizing than the next.

Adding to the chorus was a panel discussion aimed at helping entrepreneurs grow and scale their small businesses, sponsored by JPMorgan Chase.

Moderated by Alfred Edmond, Executive Editor of Black Enterprise, panelists included Mikal Quarles, Head of Diverse Business Strategies, Business Banking, JPMorgan Chase; Susie Sturdivant, Founder, Little House for Little People Early Learning Center; and Mayor of Birmingham, Randall L.

articles.title: BofA holds No. 1 position in corporate bond underwriting, with Wells Fargo moving up to No. 2 as the overall pie shrinks
articles.author: Steve Gelsi
articles.excerpt: Overall corporate bond issuance fell to $55.4 billion YTD 2023 through July from $137.5 bln in 2022, although deal-making has picked up recently.
articles.summary:
Bank of America Corp.'s investment bank BofA Securities remained the top corporate debt issuer in 2023 as of Aug. 1, while Wells Fargo Securities LLC has bumped JPMorgan Chase & Co. for the No. 2 slot, according to S&P Global Market Intelligence data.
 
All told, year-to-date U.S. corporate debt offerings handled by the largest Wall Street banks have fallen sharply to $65.8 billion as of July 31, from the corresponding year-ago total of $137.5 billion, amid a lack of deal-making in 2023. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 S&P Global Market Intelligence 
 
 
 
 
However, some encouraging signs have surfaced as spreads on high-yield corporate bonds over comparable Treasurys have tightened in recent weeks.

articles.title: Jamie Dimon, JPMorgan board defeat shareholders' Jeffrey Epstein lawsuit
articles.author: Syndicated Content
articles.excerpt: By Jonathan Stempel NEW YORK (Reuters) - A federal judge has dismissed a shareholder lawsuit accusing JPMorgan Chase Chief Executive Jamie Dimon and h...
articles.summary:
By Jonathan Stempel
NEW YORK (Reuters) – A federal judge has dismissed a shareholder lawsuit accusing JPMorgan Chase Chief Executive Jamie Dimon and his board of directors of ignoring red flags surrounding disgraced former client Jeffrey Epstein.
In a Wednesday evening decision, U.S. District Judge Jed Rakoff said shareholders led by Miami and Pittsburgh pension funds failed to first ask the bank's board directly to address their concerns, or show it would be futile to do so, before suing.
The Manhattan-based judge said he will explain his reasoning in due course.

articles.title: JPMorgan says it expects to pay about $3 billion to help refill FDIC fund
articles.author: Reuters
articles.excerpt: NEW YORK -JPMorgan Chase expects to set aside about $3 billion to replenish the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's fund once proposed rules are finalized by the bank regulator, the company…
articles.summary:
NEW YORK (Reuters) -JPMorgan Chase expects to set aside about $3 billion to replenish the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's (FDIC) fund once proposed rules are finalized by the bank regulator, the company said in a filing on Thursday. 
U.S. banking giants are expected to shoulder the bulk of costs to refill the fund, which was drained of $16 billion this year after three banks collapsed.
Wells Fargo estimated it will face a pretax "special assessment" of up to $1.8 billion, while Bank of America said it could face a pretax expense of about $1.

 has appointed

 to its Board of Directors. Anne is a senior human capital management executive with broad consumer and business-to-business leadership experience in the financial services and consumer credit sectors.

articles.title: JPMorgan Rolls Back Switzerland Bet on Multi-Family Office Team
articles.author: Myriam Balezou
articles.excerpt: JPMorgan Chase & Co. is scaling back plans to build a team in Geneva that caters for the investment firms of wealthy families, partially reversing a strategy to serve the world's super-rich.
articles.summary:
(Bloomberg) -- JPMorgan Chase & Co. is scaling back plans to build a team in Geneva that caters for the investment firms of wealthy families, partially reversing a strategy to serve the world's super-rich.
The bank wound down its standalone multi-family office team in one of the world's hotspots for wealth-management after struggling to grow the unit, according to people familiar with the matter. 
The decision stems partly from Swiss regulatory changes that have caused the number of independent wealth managers to dwindle, said the people, who asked not to be identified because the matter is private.

articles.title: Jamie Dimon, JPMorgan board defeat shareholders' Jeffrey Epstein lawsuit
articles.author: Syndicated Content
articles.excerpt: By Jonathan Stempel NEW YORK (Reuters) - A federal judge has dismissed a shareholder lawsuit accusing JPMorgan Chase Chief Executive Jamie Dimon and h...
articles.summary:
By Jonathan Stempel
NEW YORK (Reuters) – A federal judge has dismissed a shareholder lawsuit accusing JPMorgan Chase Chief Executive Jamie Dimon and his board of directors of ignoring red flags surrounding disgraced former client Jeffrey Epstein.
In a Wednesday evening decision, U.S. District Judge Jed Rakoff said shareholders led by Miami and Pittsburgh pension funds failed to first ask the bank's board directly to address their concerns, or show it would be futile to do so, before suing.
The Manhattan-based judge said he will explain his reasoning in due course.

articles.title: Bristol-Myers Squibb To Buyback $4 Bln Of Shares Under Accelerated Share Repurchase
articles.excerpt: (RTTNews) - Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. (BMY), a pharma major, said on Thursday that it has inked agreements to enter into an accelerated share repur...
articles.summary:
(RTTNews) - Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. (BMY), a pharma major, said on Thursday that it has inked agreements to enter into an accelerated share repurchase or ASR program to buy back a total of $4 billion of its shares at par value of $0.10 per share.

The ASR transactions, scheduled to be closed in the fourth quarter, will be completed under agreements with Bank of America, N.A., Citibank, N.A., JPMorgan Chase Bank, National Association and Morgan Stanley & Co. LLC.

BMS will pay the repurchase price and receive shares with a total value of 85 percent of the repurchase price based on the closing share price as of August 9.

articles.title: Jamie Dimon Faces an Uphill Battle Convincing a Jury He Didn't Know that Child Sex-Trafficker, Jeffrey Epstein, Was Financing His Operation Out of JPMorgan
articles.author: Wallstreetonparade
articles.excerpt: Free Republic Browse · Search Bloggers & Personal Topics · Post Article Skip to comments. Jamie Dimon Faces an Uphill Battle Convincing a Jury He Didn't Know that Child Sex-Trafficker, Jeffrey…
articles.summary:

Jamie Dimon Faces an Uphill Battle Convincing a Jury He Didn't Know that Child Sex-Trafficker, Jeffrey Epstein, Was Financing His Operation Out of JPMorgan
 


Wallstreetonparade ^


 | 8/9/23 | Pam Martens and Russ Martens

 
Posted on 
08/10/2023 6:34:34 AM PDT
 by 
CFW
 
Jamie Dimon is between a rock and a hard place. He is either going to have to convince a jury come October that he was left in the dark by the bank's general counsel, his compliance and money laundering executives, and the heads of his investment bank and asset and wealth division about the fact that notorious child molester Jeffrey Epstein was a client at the bank for more than a decade – which would make Dimon sound so isolated as to be unfit to be running the bank – or Dimon is going to have to admit that he lied under oath in his federal court deposition.

articles.title: Bristol Myers Sets $4 Billion Accelerated Stock Buyback >BMY
articles.excerpt: By Colin Kellaher Bristol Myers Squibb is buying back $4 billion worth of stock under accelerated repurchase agreements with Bank of America, Citibank,...
articles.summary:
By Colin Kellaher
 
Bristol Myers Squibb is buying back $4 billion worth of stock under accelerated repurchase agreements with Bank of America, Citibank, JPMorgan Chase and Morgan Stanley.
 
The New York biopharmaceutical company on Thursday said the move is part of a multi-year buyback program that will have about $2 billion remaining after the transactions.
 
 
Bristol Myers, which had nearly 2.09 billion shares outstanding as of July 20 and sports a market capitalization topping $125 billion, said it expects an initial delivery of 85% of the shares to be repurchased under the agreements, with final settlement by the end of the year.

articles.title: JPMorgan Says It Expects to Pay About $3 Billion to Help Refill FDIC Fund
articles.excerpt: In a significant move aimed at bolstering the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) fund, JPMorgan Chase, one of the largest and most prominent banks in the United States, announced its…
articles.summary:
By Charles Nwoke


In a significant move aimed at bolstering the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) fund, JPMorgan Chase, one of the largest and most prominent banks in the United States, announced its commitment to contribute approximately $3 billion. The bank's decision comes as part of a collective effort to support the FDIC in safeguarding the stability of the nation's financial system.


The FDIC serves as a crucial safety net for depositors, ensuring that their funds are protected even in the event of a bank failure.

articles.author: Megan Becka
articles.excerpt: LeBron James Family Foundation's House Three Thirty and Chase are giving away 1,000 backpacks stuffed with school supplies on Friday.
articles.summary:
AKRON, Ohio – LeBron James Family Foundation's House Three Thirty and Chase are giving away backpacks and school supplies to students at a back-to-school event on Friday, Aug. 4 from 4-8 p.m.

The event is open to all community members and will be held at House Three Thirty, 532 W. Market St.

Supplies are limited to the first 1,000 attendees, according to event organizers. Chase will also host financial health workshops for parents and kids at the event. The workshops will inform parents and kids about the importance of budgeting and smart spending when preparing for the upcoming school year.

David H. Toung Senior Analyst: Medical Devices & Healthcare Services

David covers the Pharmaceutical, Medical Devices, and Healthcare services sectors for Argus. He has more than two decades of experience in the financial analysis industry, having worked for McDonald & Co., JPMorgan Chase and Standard & Poor's, among others. His commentary has appeared on CNBC and in The New York Times. Prior to his financial career, David was a private practice attorney in New Jersey, and served as a Judicial Clerk for an Appellate Division judge in the New Jersey Superior Court.

articles.title: Jamie Dimon, JPMorgan board defeat shareholders' Jeffrey Epstein lawsuit
articles.author: Syndicated Content
articles.excerpt: By Jonathan Stempel NEW YORK (Reuters) - A federal judge has dismissed a shareholder lawsuit accusing JPMorgan Chase Chief Executive Jamie Dimon and h...
articles.summary:
By Jonathan Stempel
NEW YORK (Reuters) – A federal judge has dismissed a shareholder lawsuit accusing JPMorgan Chase Chief Executive Jamie Dimon and his board of directors of ignoring red flags surrounding disgraced former client Jeffrey Epstein.
In a Wednesday evening decision, U.S. District Judge Jed Rakoff said shareholders led by Miami and Pittsburgh pension funds failed to first ask the bank's board directly to address their concerns, or show it would be futile to do so, before suing.
The Manhattan-based judge said he will explain his reasoning in due course.

articles.title: The Tell: JPMorgan abandons U.S. recession call, instead sees ‘subpar growth' in 2024
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.excerpt: A top economist at JPMorgan Chase & Co. JPM, -0.21% no longer expects a recession to arrive in the U.S. before the end of 2023. He doesn't expect one in
articles.summary:
A top economist at JPMorgan Chase & Co. JPM, -0.21%
 no longer expects a recession to arrive in the U.S. before the end of 2023. He doesn't expect one in 2024 either, but said the risk of a potential downturn remains elevated. Michael Feroli, chief U.S. economist at JPMorgan, on Friday officially abandoned the bank's earlier recession forecast, putting the largest U.S. bank by assets more in line with others on Wall Street in thinking that a recession might be avoided even though the Federal Reserve has increased rates to a 22-year high.

articles.title: Bristol-Myers Squibb To Buyback $4 Bln Of Shares Under Accelerated Share Repurchase
articles.excerpt: Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. (BMY), a pharma major, said on Thursday that it has inked agreements to enter into an accelerated share repurchase or ASR program to buy back a total of $4 billion of its shares at par value of $0.
articles.summary:
Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. (BMY), a pharma major, said on Thursday that it has inked agreements to enter into an accelerated share repurchase or ASR program to buy back a total of $4 billion of its shares at par value of $0.10 per share.

The ASR transactions, scheduled to be closed in the fourth quarter, will be completed under agreements with Bank of America, N.A., Citibank, N.A., JPMorgan Chase Bank, National Association and Morgan Stanley & Co. LLC.

BMS will pay the repurchase price and receive shares with a total value of 85 percent of the repurchase price based on the closing share price as of August 9.

articles.summary:
(Reuters) - Shares of U.S. banks fell in premarket trading on Tuesday after Moody's downgrade of 10 mid-sized lenders reignited investor concerns about challenges facing the banking industry.

The rating agency said rising funding costs, possible decline in deposit levels and weaker profitability pose risks to the banking sector, which went through a crisis earlier this year after the collapse of three lenders.

"The Moody's announcement is a wake-up call," Stuart Cole, chief macro economist at Equiti Capital, said.

articles.title: Private Equity and College Sports Can Make a Good Team
articles.author: Adam Minter
articles.excerpt: Schools can use the cash from outside investors, which can help ensure student-athletes get the education and opportunities they are promised.
articles.summary: The athletic departments at public universities generate billions of dollars in revenue every year. Private equity investors have noticed. Late last week, Sportico reported that Florida State had hired JPMorgan Chase & Co. to explore how its athletic department could raise money from institutional investors. It could be a winning combination. Despite huge sums already being generated by college football programs, there's more to be had. Private investors could help athletic departments obtain it.

articles.title: Seattle Office of Economic Development announces new program giving Seattle business owners the tools to stay in their communities
articles.author: Erika Lindsay
articles.excerpt: Business Community Ownership Fund (BCO Fund) call for project ideas The Seattle Office of Economic Development (OED) and the National Development Council (NDC) are partnering to offer a new Business…
articles.summary:
by 
Erika Lindsay
 on 
August 9, 2023
 
 


 Business Community Ownership Fund (BCO Fund) call for project ideas
 
 
The Seattle Office of Economic Development (OED) and the National Development Council (NDC) are partnering to offer a new Business Community Ownership Fund (BCO Fund) to preserve and strengthen the businesses that make our communities vibrant which are at risk of displacement due to the increased costs of commercial leases in Seattle. The BCO Fund provides Black, Indigenous, and people of color (BIPOC) business owners the opportunity to invest in partnerships that will lead to long-term control and ownership of their own commercial spaces, thereby lowering tenant costs, increasing business incomes, and fostering economic stability.

articles.title: Massachusetts Regulators Launch Probe Into AI in Securities Industry
articles.author: Reuters
articles.excerpt: US News is a recognized leader in college, grad school, hospital, mutual fund, and car rankings. Track elected officials, research health conditions, and find news you can use in politics, business, health, and education.
articles.summary:
BOSTON (Reuters) - Massachusetts securities regulators have opened an investigation into the way investment firms use artificial intelligence in their interactions with investors in the state, citing concerns about the technology's growth and potential unchecked use.

Massachusetts Secretary of State Bill Galvin, the state's top securities regulator, on Thursday announced that his office had sent letters of inquiry to a number of firms using or developing AI for their businesses, including JPMorgan Chase and Morgan Stanley.

articles.title: Global banks rattled after Moody's cuts, Italy windfall tax
articles.author: Reuters
articles.excerpt: By Niket Nishant (Reuters) -Global bank shares skidded on Tuesday after Moody's downgraded 10 mid-sized U.S. banks and Italy approved a surprise 40%
articles.summary:
By Niket Nishant (Reuters) -Global bank shares skidded on Tuesday after Moody's downgraded 10 mid-sized U.S. banks and Italy approved a surprise 40% windfall tax on lenders, with the double-blow reigniting concerns about the challenges facing the industry. The sector has been looking to emerge from a crisis that took down three U.S. banks earlier this year and triggered a loss of confidence that engulfed Credit Suisse, which was bought out by rival UBS Group AG in a rescue deal. The big U.S. banks, although not under Moody's review, slumped in early trading, with JPMorgan Chase down 2% and Bank


The post 
Global banks rattled after Moody's cuts, Italy windfall tax
 appeared first on 
Shore News Network
.

Individual investors can boost their portfolio returns by following some of the most well-regarded investors. Warren Buffett, arguably the greatest to ever do it, gets a lot of attention thanks to his legendary track record.

's portfolio, we'll notice that one of its top holdings is

(

)
. It's the third-largest position, worth $25.6 billion (as of July 31). Buffett first purchased Amex shares about 30 years ago, and it appears he remains bullish on the business.

articles.title: Report: Florida State exploring capital equity with JPMorgan
articles.excerpt: Florida State's athletic department is looking to raise money and is working with JPMorgan Chase to try to find investors, Sportico reported Friday.
articles.summary:
Florida State's athletic department is looking to raise money and is working with JPMorgan Chase to try to find investors, Sportico reported Friday.


The report didn't specify how Florida State would use the funds, but it could be to pay a $120 million exit fee from the Atlantic Coast Conference.


The university president and athletic director said earlier this week that they are worried Florida State isn't in the financial position that it should be because of its conference affiliation and could leave the ACC.

articles.author: Steve Gelsi
articles.excerpt: Bank fundamental results were challenged during the quarter, but results were better than worst-case fears as higher interest rates boosted bank loan yields
articles.summary:
Bank fundamentals were challenged but results were better than worst-case fears as higher interest rates boosted bank loan yields, Jefferies analyst Ken Usdin said Thursday in the firm's summary of second-quarter profits for the 36 large and mid-sized banks in its coverage universe.
JPMorgan Chase & Co. 
JPM, 
+0.49%
 won kudos as a winner among large-cap banks for its upward revision to $87 billion from its earlier view of $81 billion for its estimated 2023 net interest income excluding its markets results, Jefferies noted.

articles.title: Wall Street Giants Expect $8.9 Billion Hit From Bank Failures
articles.author: Tanaz Meghjani
articles.excerpt: The biggest US lenders expect to pay almost $8.9 billion to help replenish the US government's bedrock Deposit Insurance Fund after it was tapped to backstop uninsured depositors at Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank.
articles.summary:
The biggest US lenders expect to pay almost $8.9 billion to help replenish the US government's bedrock Deposit Insurance Fund after it was tapped to backstop uninsured depositors at Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank.

Citigroup Inc. expects to contribute as much as $1.5 billion to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. 's pot that was depleted to protect deposits at the two failed lenders, making it the last of the country's biggest banks to disclose the set-asides. In total, the six largest lenders forecast covering 56% of the $15.

articles.title: Massachusetts regulators launch probe into AI in securities industry
articles.author: Thomson Reuters
articles.excerpt: BOSTON (Reuters) - Massachusetts securities regulators have opened an investigation into the way investment firms use artificial intelligence in their interactions with investors in the state, citing…
articles.summary:
BOSTON (Reuters) – Massachusetts securities regulators have opened an investigation into the way investment firms use artificial intelligence in their interactions with investors in the state, citing concerns about the technology's growth and potential unchecked use.
Massachusetts Secretary of State Bill Galvin, the state's top securities regulator, on Thursday announced that his office had sent letters of inquiry to a number of firms using or developing AI for their businesses, including JPMorgan Chase and Morgan Stanley.

(Bloomberg) -- JPMorgan Chase & Co. economists scrapped their call for a recession in the US, joining a growing number of forecasters who now expect the economy to avert the downturn that was once viewed as inevitable. 
The bank, which had previously said it expected a recession to begin in 2023, now sees continued expansion this year and 'modest, sub-par growth' in 2024 as the most likely scenario.

articles.title: Bristol Myers Sets $4 Billion Accelerated Stock Buyback
articles.excerpt: By Colin Kellaher Bristol Myers Squibb is buying back $4 billion worth of stock under accelerated repurchase agreements with Bank of America, Citibank, JPMorgan Chase and Morgan Stanley. The New York…
articles.summary:
By Colin Kellaher 



 


 Bristol Myers Squibb is buying back $4 billion worth of stock under accelerated repurchase agreements with Bank of America, Citibank, JPMorgan Chase and Morgan Stanley. 


 The New York biopharmaceutical company on Thursday said the move is part of a multi-year buyback program that will have about $2 billion remaining after the transactions. 


 Bristol Myers, which had nearly 2.09 billion shares outstanding as of July 20 and sports a market capitalization topping $125 billion, said it expects an initial delivery of 85% of the shares to be repurchased under the agreements, with final settlement by the end of the year.

articles.title: Dubai tower draws investor interest
articles.author: Tan Kw
articles.excerpt: Dubai tower draws investor interest
articles.summary:
China Investment Corp, KLCC Property Holdings Bhd and Saudi Arabia's Hassana are among potential bidders for a stake in an office tower in the heart of Dubai's financial district, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

Its owners, Brookfield Asset Management and state-owned Investment Corp of Dubai, may sell a stake of as much as 49% in ICD Brookfield Place, whose tenants include JPMorgan Chase & Co and Bank of America Corp, the people said, asking not to be identified because the talks are private.

articles.title: JPMorgan backs off recession call even with ‘very elevated' risks
articles.author: Jeff Cox Cnbc
articles.excerpt: Economists at the country's largest bank bailed on their recession call, joining a growing chorus that now thinks a contraction is no longer inevitable.
articles.summary:
JPMorgan Chase economists on Friday bailed on their recession call.
 
"Given this growth, we doubt the economy will quickly lose enough momentum to slip into a mild contraction as early as next quarter, as we had previously projected," the bank's lead economist said.
 
Michael Feroli added that risk is not completely off the table. Specifically, he cited the danger of Fed policy that has seen 11 interest rate hikes implemented since March 2022.
 
JPMorgan Chase economists on Friday bailed on their recession call, joining a growing Wall Street chorus that now thinks a contraction is no longer inevitable.

articles.title: Super-popular doctor canceled by Chase Bank warns 'social credit system' is already here
articles.author: Peter Labarbera
articles.excerpt: JP Morgan Chase Bank has a growing reputation as a "woke" bank that shills for leftist social causes even as it openly discriminates against conservatives, most recently shutting down the business and…
articles.summary:
JP Morgan Chase Bank has a growing reputation as a "woke" bank that 
shills for leftist social causes
 even as it openly discriminates against conservatives, most recently shutting down the business and personal accounts of COVID-19 dissenter 
Dr. Joseph Mercola
, a super-popular proponent of alternative medicine and marketer of natural health products.


But it didn't stop there: as 
WND reported
, on July 13 Chase also shut down the accounts of 
Mercola Market's
 CEO, CFO and even those of their respective spouses and children.
articles.authors: A Former Contributing Editor,Accuracy In Media,His Wife,Lifesitenews.Com,Peter LaBarbera,Wnd Staff

articles.title: Goldman, JPMorgan Say Buy Treasuries After Last Week's Selloff
articles.author: Ye Xie
articles.excerpt: For the $25 trillion Treasury market, it was a three-pronged attack. Bond supply jumped just as Fitch Ratings stripped the US of its AAA halo. Days earlier, the Bank of Japan stoked speculation that a…
articles.summary:
The information you requested is not available at this time, please check back again soon.
 
 
 Video
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
(Bloomberg) -- For the $25 trillion Treasury market, it was a three-pronged attack. Bond supply jumped just as Fitch Ratings stripped the US of its AAA halo. Days earlier, the Bank of Japan stoked speculation that a new era of capital repatriation may be nigh. 
Now, Wall Street can agree on one thing: The ensuing Treasury selloff that pushed 10-year and 30-year yields close to multi-year highs last week was overdone.

articles.title: The 10 Biggest Banks in the US
articles.author: Toni Husbands
articles.excerpt: Despite a few shake ups in the most recent Fed ranking, the top 10 list of the largest banks in the US by assets owned remains fairly consistent.
articles.summary:
One of the biggest US banks' consolidated assets shrank slightly from the first to second quarter of this year, according to the Federal Reserve. Since March 2023, JPMorgan Chase's assets declined from $3.48 trillion to $3.26 trillion. Despite this drop, Chase retains the top spot as the largest US bank, a position it's held for more than 20 years.
 
The list of the top 10 US-based banks has remained fairly consistent over time, even with several high profile bank failures this year -- JPMorgan Chase acquired banks such as 
First Republic
 and Silicon Valley Banks.

articles.title: JPMorgan backs off recession call even with ‘very elevated' risks
articles.author: Jeff Cox Cnbc
articles.excerpt: Economists at the country's largest bank bailed on their recession call, joining a growing chorus that now thinks a contraction is no longer inevitable.
articles.summary:
JPMorgan Chase economists on Friday bailed on their recession call.

"Given this growth, we doubt the economy will quickly lose enough momentum to slip into a mild contraction as early as next quarter, as we had previously projected," the bank's lead economist said.

Michael Feroli added that risk is not completely off the table. Specifically, he cited the danger of Fed policy that has seen 11 interest rate hikes implemented since March 2022.

JPMorgan Chase economists on Friday bailed on their recession call, joining a growing Wall Street chorus that now thinks a contraction is no longer inevitable.

articles.title: US bank stocks drop after Moody's downgrade
articles.author: Syndicated Content
articles.excerpt: (Reuters) - Shares of U.S. banks fell in premarket trading on Tuesday after Moody's downgrade of 10 mid-sized lenders reignited investor concerns abou...
articles.summary:
(Reuters) – Shares of U.S. banks fell in premarket trading on Tuesday after Moody's downgrade of 10 mid-sized lenders reignited investor concerns about challenges facing the banking industry.

The rating agency said rising funding costs, possible decline in deposit levels and weaker profitability pose risks to the banking sector, which went through a crisis earlier this year after the collapse of three lenders.

'The Moody's announcement is a wake-up call,' Stuart Cole, chief macro economist at Equiti Capital, said.

articles.title: Principal welcomes new managing director of global fixed income
articles.author: Business Record Staff
articles.excerpt: Principal Asset Management announced Monday that Michael Goosay has joined the firm as managing director of global fixed income and portfolio manager on select strategies. Goosay will take on…
articles.summary:
Michael Goosay

Principal Asset Management announced Monday that Michael Goosay has joined the firm as managing director of global fixed income and portfolio manager on select strategies. Goosay will take on leadership responsibilities across the platform, including becoming a portfolio manager on Principal Fixed Income's short-term income, core, core plus and U.S./global multi-sector strategies and associated products. 'Michael's experience, leadership and creativity will further bolster our already strong global fixed-income capabilities,' Kamal Bhatia, global head of investments for Principal Asset Management, said in a news release.

articles.title: Banks' Near $50 Billion In Stock Losses Set Up Market For One Of 2023's Worst Days
articles.author: Derek Saul
articles.excerpt: Shares of the 15 largest American banks each fell 2% or more after Moody's issued a chilly update on the closely-watched sector.
articles.summary:
Topline

Wobbly investor confidence in banks caused major stock indexes to suffer significant losses Tuesday, a familiar tune not heard in months.

Key Facts

Moody's downgraded its rating for 10 regional institutions including M&T Bank late Monday, put larger banks like State Street, Truist and U.S. Bancorp on watch for a downgrade and issued a negative outlook warning for firms including Capital One and PNC.

PNC, Truist and U.S. Bancorp's 4% share price drops were among the steepest of any stock by 10:15 a.

articles.title: JPMorgan Chase Economists Abandon Recession Call as Data Indicates Possible Soft Landing
articles.author: John Mahon
articles.excerpt: JPMorgan Chase economists withdrew their recession prediction, citing positive data and the resolution of political issues as contributing factors. However, risks remain.
articles.summary:
JPMorgan Chase economists on Friday bailed on their recession call, joining a growing Wall Street chorus that now thinks a contraction is no longer inevitable.


While noting that risks are still high and growth ahead is likely to be slow, the bank's forecasters think the data flow indicates a soft landing is possible. That comes despite a series of interest rate hikes enacted with the express intent of slowing the economy, and several other substantial headwinds.


Michael Feroli, chief economist at the nation's largest bank, told clients that recent metrics are indicating growth of about 2.

articles.title: Banks' Near $50 Billion Stock Losses Set Up Market For Among Worst Days Of 2023
articles.author: Derek Saul
articles.excerpt: Shares of the 15 largest American banks each fell 2% or more after Moody's issued a chilly update on the closely-watched sector.
articles.summary:
Topline

Wobbly investor confidence in banks caused major stock indexes to suffer significant losses Tuesday, a familiar tune not heard in months.

Key Facts

Moody's downgraded its rating for 10 regional institutions including M&T Bank late Monday, put larger banks like State Street, Truist and U.S. Bancorp on watch for a downgrade and issued a negative outlook warning for firms including Capital One and PNC.

PNC, Truist and U.S. Bancorp's 4% share price drops were among the steepest of any stock by 10:15 a.

articles.author: Syndicated Content
articles.excerpt: (Reuters) - Shares of U.S. banks fell in premarket trading on Tuesday after Moody's downgrade of 10 mid-sized lenders reignited investor concerns abou...
articles.summary:
(Reuters) – Shares of U.S. banks fell in premarket trading on Tuesday after Moody's downgrade of 10 mid-sized lenders reignited investor concerns about challenges facing the banking industry.
The rating agency said rising funding costs, possible decline in deposit levels and weaker profitability pose risks to the banking sector, which went through a crisis earlier this year after the collapse of three lenders.
'The Moody's announcement is a wake-up call,' Stuart Cole, chief macro economist at Equiti Capital, said.

articles.title: UPDATE 1-JPMorgan says it expects to pay about $3 billion to help refill FDIC fund
articles.author: Nupur Anand
articles.excerpt: JPMorgan Chase expects to set aside about $3 billion to replenish the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's (FDIC) fund once proposed rules are finalized by the bank regulator, the company said in a…
articles.summary:
(Updates context on other banks from paragraph 2, adds byline)
By Nupur Anand
NEW YORK, Aug 3 (Reuters) -
JPMorgan Chase expects to set aside about $3 billion to replenish the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's (FDIC) fund once proposed rules are finalized by the bank regulator, the company said in a filing on Thursday.
U.S. banking giants are expected to shoulder the bulk of costs to refill the fund, which was drained of $16 billion this year after three banks collapsed.
Wells Fargo
estimated it will face a pretax "special assessment" of up to $1.

articles.title: Elon Musk's illegal flashing X logo at HQ leads to $4,500 in fines: report
articles.author: Shannon Thaler
articles.excerpt: The landlord of X's headquarter in San Francisco has been fined $4,447 over Elon Musk's illegal strobe-lit "X" sign. It's unclear if Musk will be on the hook for any penalties.
articles.summary:
Elon Musk's publicity stunt to put a strobe-lit giant 'X' atop the headquarters housing his rebranded social media company has cost the building's landlord nearly $4,500, according to a report.

Musk enraged neighbors and city officials by putting up the structure without a permit last month as part of his campaign to promote X, the company formerly known as Twitter.

The city quickly told the landlord, Shorenstein, to dismantle the steel structure and issued a slew of summonses, the San Francisco Department of Building Inspection told the San Francisco Chronicle.

articles.title: Wall Street's Return-to-Office Crackdown Could Backfire
articles.author: Lananh Nguyen
articles.excerpt: Financial firms that enforce strict return-to-office mandates could drive employees to leave, according to a study published Tuesday by accounting firm Deloitte.
articles.summary:
Financial firms that enforce strict return-to-office mandates could drive employees to leave, according to a study published Tuesday by accounting firm Deloitte.

Of 700 financial executives surveyed by Deloitte, 66% who worked remotely part time said they would likely quit if they were ordered to return to the office five days a week.

"Professionals - men and women alike - whose work and personal lives have been reshaped by remote work largely want to maintain flexibility even if it comes at a personal cost," Deloitte said.

articles.title: Massachusetts regulators investigate investment firms' use of AI
articles.author: Eric Revell
articles.excerpt: Massachusetts is investigating the use of artificial intelligence by investment firms in client-facing tools and marketing materials to ensure there are safeguards.
articles.summary:
Securities regulators from Massachusetts are investigating how investment firms are using 
artificial intelligence (AI)
 in the course of their interactions with investors due to concerns about the technology's potentially unchecked use.
 
Massachusetts Secretary of State Bill Galvin, whose agency is the top securities regulator in the state, announced Thursday that his office sent letters of inquiry to several firms that are either using or in the process of developing AI tools to be used in their businesses.

articles.title: Strategists scramble to catch up as S&P 500 rally rumbles on
articles.author: Tan Kw
articles.excerpt: Strategists scramble to catch up as S&P 500 rally rumbles on
articles.summary:
There's a shift in tone happening across Wall Street.

Oppenheimer Asset Management's Chief investment strategist John Stoltzfus lifted his target on the S&P 500 index to a Street high, a day after Morgan Stanley's Michael Wilson, one of the market's leading doomsayers, sounded less bearish than usual.

Stoltzfus now sees the S&P 500 index hitting 4,900 by the end of the year, leaving room for another 7% gain. The target would mark a new record for the gauge, and one that plays out against bearish predictions by bigwigs such as Wilson, JPMorgan Chase & Co's Marko Kolanovic and Bank of America Corp's Michael Hartnett.
